name: Mona Lisa
facts: Once hung as bathroom decoration in King Francis I's royal apartments, where steam damaged the paint and required restoration.
Leonardo never delivered the painting to the Giocondo family who commissioned it, keeping it with him until his death.
Leonardo worked on it intermittently for over 16 years, from 1503 until his death in 1519.
The painting was stolen in 1911 by Italian handyman Vincenzo Peruggia, who kept it hidden in his apartment for two years.
There's a contemporary copy at the Prado Museum in Madrid, painted by one of Leonardo's students sitting beside him brush-stroke by brush-stroke.

name: The Starry Night
facts: The bright 'star' to the right of the cypress tree is actually the planet Venus, which was visible at dawn in 1889.
Van Gogh painted the view from his asylum window 21 times, but this is the only nighttime version.
Van Gogh considered the painting a failure and was critical of it in letters to his brother Theo.
Van Gogh's vivid use of yellow may have been caused by taking too much digitalis, a treatment for his epilepsy.
The painting was valued at an estimated $100 million and Van Gogh only sold one documented painting during his lifetime.

name: Campbell's Soup Cans
facts: Warhol ate Campbell's soup for lunch every day for 20 years, calling it 'the same thing over and over again'.
Created exactly 32 canvases representing every non-frozen Campbell's soup flavor available in 1962.
A rival gallery mocked the exhibition by displaying actual soup cans for 'two for 33 cents' versus Warhol's $100 paintings.
Dealer Irving Blum eventually bought back all sold pieces to keep the series together, paying Warhol $1,000 for the complete set.
The series was later sold to MoMA for upwards of $15 million after Blum kept them for 34 years.

name: The Persistence of Memory
facts: Dalí said the melting clocks were inspired by Camembert cheese melting in the sun, not Einstein's theory of relativity.
Despite its fame, the painting is only 9.5 x 13 inches—slightly larger than notebook paper.
The ants covering the orange clock symbolize decay and death, a motif Dalí used throughout his career.
Dalí was only 28 years old when he painted this masterpiece in 1931.

name: The Great Wave off Kanagawa
facts: Hokusai changed his name more than 30 times throughout his career, signing this work 'From the brush of Hokusai, who changed his name to Iitsu'.
Originally cost the equivalent of a noodle soup and was mass-produced for the growing Japanese middle class.
Used newly imported Prussian blue pigment, which was much more concentrated and potent than traditional Japanese blues.
The wave measures between 32-39 feet (10-12 meters) high, calculated using the boats as reference scale.
Shows three oshiokuri-bune (fast fish transport boats) with 30 men total, though only 22 are visible in the composition.

name: Composition with Red, Blue and Yellow
facts: Mondrian intentionally left visible brushstrokes on the canvas, imbuing the geometric work with a human touch.
The black lines are treated as planes of pigment themselves, sometimes stopping short of the canvas edges to create dynamic tension.
The large red square is carefully balanced by smaller blue and yellow rectangles, demonstrating harmony through asymmetry.
This style, which Mondrian called 'Neoplasticism', aimed to express universal harmony through primary colors and straight lines.

name: Girl with a Pearl Earring
facts: This painting is a 'tronie'—a Dutch term for a character study of an imaginary figure, not a specific person.
The artwork is often called the 'Mona Lisa of the North' due to the subject's enigmatic and captivating expression.
Some experts believe the famous pearl earring might not be a real pearl, but rather polished tin or glass.
Vermeer used ultramarine for the blue turban, a pigment that was more expensive than gold in the 17th century.

name: Sunflowers
facts: This is one of at least 11 paintings Van Gogh created of sunflowers, which he chose for their 'coarse and unrefined' beauty.
He originally painted the series to decorate the 'Yellow House' in Arles for his friend and fellow artist, Paul Gauguin.
For Van Gogh, the sunflowers were a symbol of 'gratitude'.
Despite their fame today, Van Gogh never sold any of his sunflower paintings during his lifetime.

name: Royal Red and Blue
facts: The painting exemplifies Rothko's signature style of using large, soft-edged blocks of color to evoke deep emotional responses.
He insisted his paintings be displayed in dim lighting and viewed up close to create an immersive, spiritual experience.
Rothko did not see his works as decorative; he wanted viewers to have a powerful, personal encounter with them.
The intense red and deep blue fields create a dramatic contrast that invites meditative contemplation.

name: Three Musicians
facts: The three figures are believed to be a tribute to Picasso (the Harlequin) and his two poet friends, Guillaume Apollinaire and Max Jacob.
The painting serves as a memorial, as Apollinaire had died and Jacob had recently entered a monastery.
Although it's an oil painting, it was designed to look like a collage of cut-out paper, a style known as Synthetic Cubism.
Picasso actually painted two almost identical versions of 'Three Musicians' in the summer of 1921.
